subSections.title: Readings
Compounds
Noun
Usage notes
subSections.text:
* When scientifically referring to humans, this term is often spelled in katakana, as {{m|ja|ヒト}}.
* From {{w|Old Japanese}} or {{w|Middle Japanese}} development, ''hito'' is sometimes shifted to ''-uto'', ''-udo'', ''-to'', ''-tto'', or ''-do''.

subSections.title: Derived terms
Etymology 2
Derived terms
subSections.text:
* {{ja-r|人%前|にん%まえ}}
* {{ja-r|旅%人|たび%にん}}

subSections.title: Derived terms
Usage notes
subSections.text: The ''-nin'' reading is commonly used when counting three or more people. When counting one or two persons as in {{m|ja|一人|tr=hitori||one person}} or {{m|ja|二人|tr=futari||two people}}, the reading is {{m|ja|り|tr=-ri}} or {{m|ja|たり|tr=-tari}}.
